awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a Novel Biocontainment/Biosafety Platform Using Synthetic Auxotrophs
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a novel system that will increase the safety and productivity of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). GMOs enablie novel live therapeutics, agricultural products, and bio-based consumer products. However, a key challenge is the lack of available tools to easily control the behavior of GMOs. This proposal will develop a technology that can be used to ensure containment of GMOs by tying their survival to the presence of specific control chemicals. The core technology is based on cells that have been engineered to alter their behavior in response to specific chemical signals, and the goal of this project is to expand the portfolio of proteins (and thus behaviors) that can be controlled by chemical inputs. This addresses concern surrounding the use and possible escape of GMOs that may have unknown consequences. 

The proposed project will establish a portfolio of chemically-controlled essential genes. This will be accomplished by protein engineering and simultaneously constructing 12,000 protein libraries spanning 200 different essential genes. Using targeted genome integration, this library of libraries will be integrated into the genome of Escherichia coli. Phenotypic characterization of the library using positive and negative (chemical) selections followed by next-generation DNA sequencing will be used to uncover the function (lethal, viable, or conditional) of individual protein designs. This dataset will illuminate the relationship between structure, sequence, and function for design of chemically-controlled proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF SBIR project sought to establish an engineering platform for imposing chemical control over cell behavior. Chemical control over biological behavior enables cells to be optimized for high value biomanufacturing applications. The project had 3 key objectives, all of which were successfully completed:

 

  1. Objective 1. Perform domain insertion profiling of the entire Escherichia coli essential proteome

  2. Objective 2. Phenotypic binning of selectable allosteric Ligand Binding Domain (LBD) library using positive and negative selection

  3. Objective 3. Use Next Generation Sequence (NGS) to identify SLIDE alleles and quantitatively profile domain insertions (completed in collaboration with Professor Philip Romero)

 

We successfully developed a multiplexed, genome-wide domain insertion strategy in order to install chemical control elements across the entire E. coli essential proteome. We optimized a triple-nested protein construct that enabled in-frame insertion of a selectable, chemically controlled allosteric element into arbitrary proteins of interest (POI). We used large-scale gene chip synthesis to target 12,000 different insertion sights. Lambda Red based recombineering allowed us to perform a single-step, highly multiplexed genome integration campaign that targeted in-frame insertion of chemically-controlled, selectable allosteric elements to the majority of E. coli?s structurally resolved essential proteome. Successful installation of 5 different multiplex library designs completed our first objective of performing domain insertion profiling of the entire Escherichia coli essential proteome.

 

We successfully performed positive and negative genetic selections to enrich conditional (chemically controlled), lethal, and viable phenotypes generated by the genome-wide allosteric ligand binding domain insertion libraries. The enrichment step yielded ~100X enrichment for ligand dependent phenotypes, allowing for easily visible, chemically controlled viability of a large percentage of the library population. Dynamic range may require additional improvement for biocontainment applications as there may still be background growth in the restrictive condition. However, in the context of optimizing cell behavior for biomanufacturing applications, a diversity of dynamic ranges is desirable. Successful positive and negative selection to enrich and phenotypically bin the phenotypes generated by the multiplex insertion library, completed the second milestone.

 

We successfully performed DNA target enrichment and NGS on the genomic DNA libraries generated in the previous step. The third objective was to use NGS to identify candidate ligand dependent alleles and to profile domain insertion permissibility of the multiplexed library designs. This was accomplished by counting occurrences of selectable LBD insertion events in different library conditions. A target enrichment strategy was developed that allowed us to efficiently amplify the chemical control module insertion sites. After optimization, the approach was successfully employed to enrich the genomic sequences with the selectable allosteric element. Preliminary NGS was performed on one library. Among the designed sequences, enrichments for rplK, ispB, mrdA, roE, rsfA, dnaE, and prfA were observed, while depletion of non-ligand dependent sequences prmC, leuS, ptsI was observed. Surprisingly and interestingly, significant enrichment was observed for many more constructs that were not designed and are believed to have appeared through off-target integration, indicating potentially easier and cheaper engineering approaches. This completed the third and final milestone of the project.

 

In summary, this project successfully developed a selectable genetic system for applying chemical control of cell behavior using a multiplexed, in-frame, genome engineering strategy, leveraging a NGS-based readout to identify phenotypic outcomes:

 

  • A novel selectable allosteric domain was developed to enable application of chemical control over cell behavior.

  • A target enrichment strategy based on DNA fragmentation, circularization, and inverse PCR amplification was established.

  • NGS analysis of libraries readily identified both designed and unexpected conditional phenotypes.

 

Our approach enables high content sequence-function analysis of chemically-controlled cell behavior at large scale and with ease. The components developed during this project form the foundation of a closed-loop cell and protein engineering framework. Computational and AI-guided protein design are being leveraged to increase cell engineering efficiency. The richness of functional diversity observed during this project indicates that Synvivia?s technology provides a promising and unexplored avenue for driving value by optimizing cell behavior for a range of different biomanufacturing processes.
